item.title: 1: Linear Regression with Single Regressor
item.description: Contents 1.1 Introduction 1.2 Linear Regression 1.3 The OLS estimator 1.4 Measures of fit 1.5 The sensitivity of OLS to large outliers 1.6 Exercise 1.1 Introduction Reference book (Theory): Introduction to Econometrics by Stock and Watson, 3e. The data are taken from the Companion Website for Introduction to Econometrics book. 1.2 Linear Regression Objective : Generate Figure 4.2 Figure 1: Scatterplot of TestScore vs Student-Teacher ratio (California School District Data Objective : Generate Figure 4.

item.title: 2: Linear Regression with Multiple Regressors
item.description: Contents 2.1 Introduction 2.2 Omitted variable bias 2.3 The Multiple Regression Model 2.4 Multicollinearity 2.5 Exercise 2.1 Introduction Reference book (Theory): Introduction to Econometrics by Stock and Watson, 3e. The data are taken from the Companion Website for Introduction to Econometrics book. 2.2 Omitted variable bias Example #1: Percentage of English learners What was our previous assessment about testscr? We estimated the linear model \(\hat{testscr} = 698.

item.title: 3: Hypothesis tests and confidence intervals 1
item.description: Contents 3.1 Testing Hypothesis Concerning the slope Coefficients 3.2 Confidence intervals for a regression coefficient 3.3 Regression when \(X\) is a binary variable 3.4 Heteroskedasticity and Homoskedasticity 3.5 Exercise 3.1 Testing Hypothesis Concerning the slope Coefficients Do smaller classes lead to higher scores? Our regression equation is \(\hat{TestScore} = \beta_0 + \beta_1 STR\) Null hypothesis: \(H_0: \beta_1 = 0\) Alternative hypothesis: \(H_0: \beta_1 < 0\) # print out just the coefficients summary(lm_model1)$coefficients ## Estimate Std.

item.title: 4: Hypothesis tests and confidence intervals 2
item.description: Contents 4.1 Hypothesis Tests and Confidence Intervals for a Single Coefficient 4.2 Tests of Joint Hypotheses 4.3 Model Specification for Multiple Regression 4.4 Analysis of the testscr data set 4.5 Exercise 4.1 Hypothesis Tests and Confidence Intervals for a Single Coefficient Introduction Like all estimators, the OLS estimator has sampling uncertainty because its value differs from one sample to the next. This chapter presents methods for quantifying the sampling uncertainty of the OLS estimator through the use of standard errors, statistical hypothesis tests, and confidence intervals.

item.title: 5: Nonlinear Regression Functions
item.description: Contents 5.1 A General Strategy for Modelling Nonlinear Regression Functions 5.2 Interactions between independent variables 5.3 Example: The demand for economics journals 5.4 Nonlinear Effects on Test Scores of the Student-Teacher Ratio 5.5 Exercise 5.1 A General Strategy for Modelling Nonlinear Regression Functions What is wrong with the linear fit? The linear regression line seems to overestimate the true relationship when income is very high or very low and underestimates it for the middle income group.
